skill.description: C4 architectural modeling for documenting software architecture. Use when creating architecture diagrams, planning new systems, communicating with stakeholders, or conducting architecture reviews.
skill.summary: Create hierarchical architecture diagrams at four abstraction levels using C4 model and Mermaid syntax

content.user_title: Create C4 Architecture Diagrams with Mermaid
content.value_statement: Software architecture diagrams are often inconsistent and hard to maintain across teams. This skill provides structured guidance for creating clear, hierarchical architecture diagrams using the C4 model methodology with Mermaid syntax.
actual_capabilities: Generate C4 Context diagrams showing system boundaries and external actors
Create C4 Container diagrams with technology stack specifications
Build C4 Component diagrams detailing internal module structures
Provide level-appropriate guidance to prevent abstraction mixing
Reference comprehensive Mermaid syntax for all C4 diagram types
limitations: Does not generate diagrams automatically, provides syntax and guidance only
Requires manual creation of diagrams using Mermaid-compatible tools
Limited to C4 methodology, not suitable for other architecture frameworks
Does not validate diagram correctness or architectural decisions

use_cases.title: New System Architecture Planning
use_cases.description: Design and document architecture for a new microservices platform starting with context diagrams and progressively zooming into container and component levels.

use_cases.title: Legacy System Documentation
use_cases.description: Create comprehensive architecture documentation for existing systems to improve team understanding and onboarding.

use_cases.title: Stakeholder Communication
use_cases.description: Generate appropriate-level diagrams for different audiences, from executive context diagrams to detailed component views for developers.

output_examples.input: Create a C4 Context diagram for a task management system
output_examples.output: A Mermaid C4Context diagram showing Person elements for team members and managers, the central task management System, and System_Ext elements for external calendar and notification services with labeled relationships

output_examples.input: Generate a C4 Container diagram for the authentication service
output_examples.output: A Mermaid C4Container diagram within a System_Boundary showing Container elements for web UI with React, API with Node.js, ContainerDb for PostgreSQL user store, ContainerDb for Redis session cache, with technology labels and relationship descriptions

best_practices: Always start at Level 1 Context diagram before creating detailed Container or Component diagrams to establish the big picture
Never mix abstraction levels in a single diagram such as showing both containers and components together
Include technology choices and clear descriptions for all elements at Level 2 and above to provide useful documentation
anti_patterns: Creating a Container diagram without first having a Context diagram that shows where the system fits in its environment
Showing implementation details like specific classes or functions in Context or Container level diagrams
Creating Code level diagrams for simple CRUD operations or frequently changing code that will quickly become outdated

faq.question: What is the C4 model?
faq.answer: The C4 model is a hierarchical approach to software architecture diagrams with four levels: Context shows the system in its environment, Container shows major components, Component shows internal structure, and Code shows implementation details.

faq.question: When should I use each C4 level?
faq.answer: Use Context for all stakeholders to show the big picture, Container for technical teams to show architecture, Component for developers working on specific parts, and Code sparingly for complex areas requiring detailed documentation.

faq.question: Can I mix different levels in one diagram?
faq.answer: No, mixing abstraction levels creates confusion. Each diagram should focus on one level. Create separate diagrams for different zoom levels and link them together.

faq.question: What tools can render Mermaid C4 diagrams?
faq.answer: Mermaid diagrams can be rendered in GitHub, GitLab, Visual Studio Code with extensions, Notion, Confluence, and many documentation tools that support Mermaid syntax.

faq.question: How many elements should be in a C4 diagram?
faq.answer: Context diagrams should have 5 to 10 elements, Container diagrams 10 to 15, and Component diagrams 10 to 20. If you exceed these counts, consider splitting into multiple diagrams.

faq.question: Do I need to create all four levels?
faq.answer: No, most systems only need Context and Container levels. Use Component for complex areas and Code level very sparingly for critical logic that requires detailed documentation.
